header.div: Read this sample answer to the Writing Task in the previous exercise. Complete the letter by dragging the correct word or phrase into each gap.

div.p: You must be really excited about moving to Sydney. How are all the preparations going? In your letter you ask if I've got any advice about how to improve your English before you leave. Well, I've given it some thought and here are a few ideas.

Speaking is probably going to be the most useful skill so, if I were you, try and speak in English as much as possible. And you should do a short, intensive oral course before you go too if you have time. I wouldn't buy one of those language courses on tape though because they're expensive and you don't get the opportunity to interact with other people.

As for your listening skills, tune into English language programmes on television and the radio whenever you can. Also, don't forget that lots of Australian, British and American websites have audio that you can listen to so I'd make the most of the Internet if .

Browsing the Internet will also help extend your vocabulary, but you read books, newspapers and magazines as well. You'd get a good English-English dictionary too. you should throw away your bilingual one, but only use it when you really have to!
Well, I have to get back to work now. If you need any more advice, don't hesitate to get in touch.

section.p: You should spend about 20 minutes on this task.

p.b: One of your penfriends is going to emigrate to Australia in a few months. They want to improve their English before they leave and have asked for your advice.
Write a letter to your penfriend and give them advice on how to improve their speaking, listening and vocabulary.

section.p: You should write at least 150 words.
You do NOT need to write your own address.
